intro: Dysophylla, commonly known as the sea holly, is a genus of flowering plants belonging to the family Goodeniaceae. It is characterized by its unique, often spiny leaves and showy, blue or purple flowers that bloom in spring. These plants are typically found in coastal areas and rocky habitats, where they thrive in well-drained soils. Dysophylla species are generally low-growing shrubs or herbs, with some varieties reaching up to 1 meter in height. Their ecological importance includes providing habitat and food for various insects and coastal wildlife.
